objtitle.title: *Sketch for "Tiriel Denouncing his Sons and Daughters"*

objdescid.compdate: c. 1789Some scholars have argued for a slightly earlier date for Blake's *Tiriel* manuscript and the wash drawings illustrating it, and hence by implication a slightly earlier date for all preliminary sketches for those wash drawings. See David Bindman, *Blake as an Artist* (Oxford: Phaidon, 1977) 43-44.

provenance.name: Whitworth Art Gallery
provenance.note: Inherited by Blake's wife Catherine at his death in 1827; acquired by Frederick Tatham, probably at Catherine Blake's death in 1831; sold Sotheby's, 29 April 1862, lot 200 with 14 other works, or lot 201 with 17 other works (2s. or 3s. to the dealer Francis Harvey); William Ward, offered in his 1914 *Catalogue of Drawings, Engravings and Books*, item 1 (£8.8s.); purchased by the Whitworth Art Gallery in 1914.

repository.collection: Whitworth Art Gallery, University of Manchester

desc.objtitle: Sketch for "Tiriel Denouncing his Sons and Daughters", object 1 (Butlin 199 recto)

objnote.p: This pencil drawing is a preliminary sketch for the monochrome wash drawing, *Tiriel Denouncing His Sons and Daughters* (Butlin 198.8), an illustration to Blake's manuscript poem, *Tiriel*.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Near the center of the composition, Tiriel, an old man with a long beard, stands in profile facing right with both arms extended horizontally. He wears a gown. A straight-backed chair (perhaps a throne?) is visible behind him at left and some sort of drapery above. Two female figures, Tiriel's daughters, kneel in front of him with arms wrapped around his legs. These figures are also gowned and each extends one leg backward. A third gowned female, presumably another daughter, crouches in the lower left corner facing right and wraps her arms around her knees. To the right of a pillar or part of a wall, three male figures, Tiriel's sons, stand facing forward against the right margin of the composition. The rightmost figure has short curly hair and turns his head left, likely to look at the central old man. His mouth is open and both arms are crossed in front of his chest. With his right hand, he holds a sword aloft. The middle figure has short curly hair and a beard and wears a spiky crown. His mouth is open. With both arms bent upward, he clutches his face (or perhaps covers his ears?). The leftmost male has short hair that appears to stand on end and a beard. With an open mouth, he turns left, likely to look at Tiriel. The expressions of all three figures suggest terror or despair.

component.illusobjdesc: Near the center of the composition, Tiriel, an old man with a long beard, stands in profile facing right. He has long hair and wears a gown. He extends both arms horizontally to the right with hands raised and palms facing out; his fingers are spread. Tiriel is depicted in the act of denouncing his sons at right and daughters below.

Two gowned female figures, Tiriel's daughters, who kneel in supplicating postures facing left, cling to the knees of the old male, their father. The figure closer to the viewer has long curly hair and, with head down, bends forward to touch the standing figure's right leg with her raised left arm. Her left leg is extended backward, and she may push into the ground with the toes of her left foot.

Two gowned female figures, Tiriel's daughters, who kneel in supplicating postures facing left, cling to the knees of the old male, their father. The figure further from the viewer bends forward with head down and likely touches the standing figure with her right arm (her hand is visible directly above her companion's left hand). One of her legs is extended backward, and she may push into the ground with the toes of her foot.

A third gowned female figure, presumably another of Tiriel's daughters, crouches in the lower left corner facing right but with head turned to face away. Bending forward, she wraps her arms around her knees.

Three male figures, Tiriel's sons, stand facing forward against the right margin of the composition. The expressions of all three figures suggest terror or despair. The rightmost figure has short curly hair and turns his head left, likely to look at the central old man. His mouth is open and both arms are crossed in front of his chest. With his right hand he holds a sword aloft.
The rightmost male figure holds a sword in his right hand, which is crossed in front of his body. The sword is pointed upward.

Three male figures, Tiriel's sons, stand facing forward against the right margin of the composition. The expressions of all three figures suggest terror or despair. The middle figure has short curly hair, a beard, and wears a spiky crown. His mouth is open. With both arms bent upward, he clutches his face (or perhaps covers his ears?). The details of his clothing are indistinct, though he may wear a serpentine belt(?) and a robe or cape, most visible along the left side of his body.

Three male figures, Tiriel's sons, stand facing forward against the right margin of the composition. The expressions of all three figures suggest terror or despair. The leftmost male has short hair that appears to stand on end and a beard. With an open mouth, he turns left, likely to look at the old man. His right arm is likely extended to the right and thus obscured behind his companions. The details of his clothing are indistinct, though he may wear a robe or gown (the hem of which is visible near his right knee) and a shirt whose circular patterning may suggest armor(?).
A straight-backed chair (perhaps a throne?) is visible against the left margin behind the central male figure.

A pillar, or part of a wall, stands between the outstretched hands of the older male figure and the group of three men at right in this design. It may indicate the threshold between an interior space at left and an exterior one at right or, alternatively, two different rooms. The rectangular forms, one vertical and one diagonal, above the heads of the figures on the right are not easily identified; they may be part of the background wall or doorway.

Along the top margin of the design from the upper left corner to the central pillar, a series of diagonal lines may suggest some kind of curtain or drapery, either of which would indicate that the demarcated space is an interior one.
